Situation1: They occasionally give casual advice when asked about minor career choices.
Situation2: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Story: I glanced at the rearview mirror, watching my passenger nervously check his watch. The snow was coming down harder now, swirling in thick sheets across the windshield. He’d just asked me, in a shaky voice, if he should take the new job offer in another country—something about a better salary but leaving his family behind. As a mentor, I felt the familiar tug to offer thoughtful guidance, to help him weigh his options with care. But as a taxi driver, my focus had to be on the road, on keeping us safe and getting him to the airport before his flight left. Every minute I spent thinking about his dilemma was a minute I wasn’t fully focused on the icy streets. My mind raced, torn between the urge to help him make a life-changing decision and the responsibility to navigate the treacherous roads. The pressure from both roles pressed in on me, and I gripped the steering wheel tighter, feeling the weight of his expectations and my own.
